description: From Middle English croke, crok, from Old English *crōc (“hook, bend, crook”), from Proto-West Germanic *krōk, from Proto-Germanic *krōkaz (“bend, hook”), from Proto-Indo-European *greg- (“tracery, basket, bend”).
Cognate with Dutch kreuk (“a bend, fold, wrinkle”), Middle Low German kroke, krake (“fold, wrinkle”), Danish krog (“crook, hook”), Swedish krok (“crook, hook”), Icelandic krókur (“hook”).

entries.meaning: A bend; turn; curve; curvature; a flexure.
examples: She held the baby in the crook of her arm.

entries.meaning: A bending of the knee; a genuflection.
A bent or curved part; a curving piece or portion (of anything).
(obsolete) A lock or curl of hair.
(obsolete) A support beam consisting of a post with a cross-beam resting upon it; a bracket or truss consisting of a vertical piece, a horizontal piece, and a strut.
A specialized staff with a semi-circular bend (a "hook") at one end used by shepherds to control their herds.
examples: Even though I walk through a / valley dark as death / I fear no evil, for thou art with me, / thy staff and thy crook are my / comfort.

entries.meaning: A bishop's standard staff of office.
An artifice; a trick; a contrivance.
examples: for all your brags, hooks, and crooks

entries.meaning: A person who steals, lies, cheats or does other dishonest or illegal things; a criminal.
examples: "People have got to know whether or not their President is a crook. Well, I′m not a crook. I′ve earned everything I′ve got."

entries.meaning: (music) A small tube, usually curved, applied to a trumpet, horn, etc., to change its pitch or key.

description: From Middle English crooken, croken, crokien, from Old English *crōcian, from Proto-West Germanic *krōkōn (“to bend, wrinkle”), from the noun (see above). Cognate with Dutch kreuken (“to crease, rumple”), German Low German kröken (“to bend, offend, suppress”).

verbs.description: crook (third-person singular simple present crooks, present participle crooking, simple past and past participle crooked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bend, or form into a hook.
examples: He crooked his finger toward me.

entries.meaning: To turn from the path of rectitude; to pervert; to misapply; to twist.
examples: The referring of all to a man's self, is more tolerable in a sovereign prince; because themselves are not only themselves, but their good and evil is at the peril of the public fortune. But it is a desperate evil, in a servant to a prince, or a citizen in a republic. For whatsoever affairs pass such a man's hands, he crooketh them to his own ends; which must needs be often eccentric to the ends of his master, or state.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) Bad, unsatisfactory, not up to standard.
examples: That work you did on my car is crook, mate.
Not turning up for training was pretty crook.

entries.meaning: (Australia, New Zealand, slang) Annoyed, angry; upset.
examples: be crook at/about; go crook at
